title: Parkinson's Disease
scope: ** Diagnosis confirmation, dopaminergic therapy initiation and optimization, motor fluctuation management, and non-motor symptom treatment. Excludes Parkinson-plus syndromes (MSA, PSP, CBD, DLB - separate protocols).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; rule out anemia contributing to fatigue
Renal function for medication dosing; electrolytes
Deficiency can cause parkinsonism; common in elderly
Deficiency common; associated with falls and disease severity

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing (LRRK2, GBA, SNCA, PARK2, PINK1, DJ-1)

Essential/First-line.target: Normal (rules out structural causes, vascular parkinsonism, NPH)

Extended.timing: Diagnostic uncertainty; essential tremor vs PD
Extended.target: Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in striatum

Extended.timing: Suspected atypical parkinsonism or iron deposition

Extended.target: Reduced uptake in PD (preserved in MSA)

Rare/Specialized.target: Pattern recognition for PD vs PSP vs MSA

Acute/Emergent.indication: Admitted PD patient; DO NOT HOLD

doseOptions.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa (continue home dose) Home dose, same timing PO

dosing.instructions: Give at EXACT same times as home; crushing allowed; use NG if NPO
dosing.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa (continue home dose) Home dose, same timing PO

doseOptions.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa (NPO protocol) Home dose equivalent NG

dosing.instructions: Crush tablets; give via NG at home schedule; consult neurology for IV options if unavailable
dosing.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa (NPO protocol) Home dose equivalent NG

Acute/Emergent.indication: Off episode in clinic/ED; NPO patient

dosing.instructions: Test dose 2 mg; titrate by 1 mg to effect; max 6 mg; pretreat with trimethobenzamide

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP, nausea; may cause severe hypotension

dosing.instructions: Apply patch equivalent to oral dopamine agonist dose; onset 2-3 hours

Acute/Emergent.indication: Pretreat before apomorphine to prevent nausea

dosing.instructions: 300 mg TID starting 3 days before apomorphine initiation
Start 25/100 TID; titrate by 1 tablet q1-2wk; typical target 25/100-25/250 TID

doseOptions.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa CR (Sinemet CR) 25/100 CR qHS PO
Carbidopa-Levodopa CR (Sinemet CR) 50/200 CR BID PO

dosing.instructions: 25/100 to 50/200 CR at bedtime or BID; 70% bioavailability vs IR
dosing.orderSentence: Carbidopa-Levodopa CR (Sinemet CR) 25/100 CR qHS PO

dosing.instructions: Convert from IR using manufacturer table; typically TID dosing

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunct to levodopa; monotherapy in early PD; tremor

dosing.instructions: Start 0.125 mg TID; titrate by 0.125-0.25 mg TID q5-7 days; max 1.5 mg TID

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Impulse control disorders, somnolence, leg edema

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adjunct or monotherapy; similar to pramipexole

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg TID; titrate weekly; max 8 mg TID
Start 2 mg daily; titrate by 2 mg q1-2wk; max 24 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: MAO-B inhibitor; adjunct; mild neuroprotection theory

dosing.instructions: 5 mg at breakfast and lunch (avoid evening due to insomnia); max 10 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Insomnia, hypertensive crisis with tyramine (rare at this dose)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: MAO-B inhibitor; once daily; adjunct or monotherapy

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5-1 mg daily; max 1 mg daily

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Hypertensive crisis (rare); serotonin syndrome with other serotonergics

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: MAO-B inhibitor with additional mechanisms; adjunct in fluctuations

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; may increase to 100 mg daily after 2 weeks

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Same as rasagiline; may improve dyskinesia

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: COMT inhibitor; extends levodopa effect; wearing off

doseOptions.orderSentence: Entacapone 200 mg with each levodopa dose PO

dosing.instructions: 200 mg with each levodopa dose; max 8 doses (1600 mg)/day
dosing.orderSentence: Entacapone 200 mg with each levodopa dose PO

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: COMT inhibitor; once daily alternative to entacapone

dosing.instructions: 50 mg once daily at bedtime; take 1 hour before or after levodopa
Start 100 mg daily; titrate to 100 mg BID-TID; max 400 mg/day; dose-reduce in renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Livedo reticularis, ankle edema, confusion, hallucinations

dosing.instructions: Start 137 mg qHS; increase to 274 mg qHS after 1 week
Start 1 mg TID; titrate by 2 mg/day q3-5 days; max 15 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Cognitive impairment, dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg BID; titrate slowly; max 6 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Adenosine A2A antagonist; adjunct for OFF time

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg daily; may increase to 40 mg daily
34 mg once daily; takes 4-6 weeks for effect; no titration needed
Start 12.5-25 mg qHS; titrate slowly by 12.5-25 mg q3-7d; typical max 150 mg/day

Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.indication: Refractory psychosis; best evidence but monitoring required

dosing.instructions: Start 6.25-12.5 mg qHS; titrate by 12.5 mg q1-2wk; max 50-100 mg/day in PD

Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.monitoring: ANC weekly x 6 mo, then q2wk x 6 mo, then monthly; agranulocytosis risk

dosing.instructions: Start 1.5 mg BID or 4.6 mg/24hr patch; titrate monthly; max 6 mg BID or 13.3 mg/24hr

Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.indication: Parkinson's disease dementia; once daily option

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg qHS; increase to 10 mg after 4-6 weeks

Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.indication: Moderate-severe dementia; add to cholinesterase inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; titrate by 5 mg/wk; target 10 mg BID
Start 2.5 mg TID (before arising, before lunch, mid-afternoon); titrate by 2.5 mg/dose; max 10 mg TID; last dose by 6 PM

Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.contraindications: Supine hypertension; urinary retention; severe cardiac disease
Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.monitoring: Supine BP (must avoid lying flat for 4 hours after dose)

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg TID; titrate by 100 mg/dose q24-48h; max 600 mg TID
Start 0.1 mg daily; may increase to 0.2 mg daily; max 0.3 mg
Start 25 mg daily; titrate by 25 mg q1-2wk; typical 50-100 mg daily
Start 37.5 mg daily; titrate q1-2wk; typical 75-150 mg daily
17 g (1 capful) in 8 oz liquid daily; may increase to BID
2 tablets qHS; may increase to 4 tablets
Start 0.25-0.5 mg qHS; titrate to effect; typical 0.5-1 mg

Non-Motor Symptom Treatments.indication: REM sleep behavior disorder; sleep disturbance

dosing.instructions: Start 3-6 mg qHS; may increase to 12 mg
Start 1 mg TID; titrate to effect; max 2 mg TID
30-50 units per parotid, 10-20 units per submandibular; repeat q3-4 months

Advanced Therapies.indication: Motor fluctuations or tremor refractory to optimal medication

doseOptions.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) STN or GPi stimulation Surgical

dosing.instructions: Unilateral or bilateral; programming done over weeks post-op
dosing.orderSentence: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) STN or GPi stimulation Surgical

Advanced Therapies.contraindications: Dementia; active psychiatric disease; medical comorbidities

doseOptions.orderSentence: Levodopa-carbidopa intestinal gel (Duopa) Continuous infusion Enteral

dosing.instructions: Via PEG-J; 16-hour infusion; morning bolus + continuous rate + extra doses
dosing.orderSentence: Levodopa-carbidopa intestinal gel (Duopa) Continuous infusion Enteral

Advanced Therapies.indication: Severe motor fluctuations; not DBS candidate

doseOptions.orderSentence: Apomorphine continuous infusion 3-8 mg/hr continuous SC

dosing.instructions: Via subcutaneous pump; typical 3-8 mg/hr during waking hours
dosing.orderSentence: Apomorphine continuous infusion 3-8 mg/hr continuous SC

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorders specialist for diagnosis confirmation and advanced therapy evaluation
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, and LSVT BIG program
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation and fine motor strategies
Speech therapy (LSVT LOUD) for hypophonia and swallowing evaluation
Neuropsychology for cognitive assessment and DBS candidacy evaluation
Psychiatry for depression, anxiety, impulse control disorders, or psychosis management
Palliative care for advanced disease symptom management and goals of care
Social work for caregiver support, community resources, and disability planning
Urology for urinary symptoms not responsive to first-line treatment
Gastroenterology for severe constipation or Duopa tube placement

Patient Instructions.item: CRITICAL: Do not skip or delay levodopa doses as this can cause severe OFF episodes and immobility
Take levodopa 30-60 minutes before meals for better absorption (protein competes with levodopa transport)
Rise slowly from sitting or lying to prevent falls from orthostatic hypotension
Inform all healthcare providers about PD medications to avoid drug interactions (especially antipsychotics, antiemetics)
Report any new impulsive behaviors (gambling, shopping, hypersexuality) which may indicate impulse control disorder from dopamine agonists
Report hallucinations early as these can be managed with medication adjustment
Engage in regular exercise which may slow disease progression and improves mobility

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30-60 min, 3-5x/week) improves motor function and may be neuroprotective
Tai chi or dance-based exercise programs improve balance and reduce falls
High-fiber diet and adequate hydration to prevent constipation
Avoid medications that worsen parkinsonism (metoclopramide, prochlorperazine, haloperidol, risperidone)
Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip surfaces
Mediterranean diet may have protective benefits based on observational studies
Coffee consumption associated with reduced PD risk; continued moderate use reasonable

differential.features: Medication exposure (antipsychotics, metoclopramide); symmetric; no levodopa response
differential.tests: DaTscan normal; history of causative medication

differential.features: Stepwise progression; lower body predominant; vascular risk factors; pyramidal signs
Early falls; vertical gaze palsy; axial rigidity > limb; poor levodopa response
Severe dysautonomia; cerebellar signs; stridor; poor levodopa response
differential.tests: MRI "hot cross bun" sign; MIBG preserved

differential.features: Asymmetric rigidity; apraxia; alien limb; cortical sensory loss
Dementia before or within 1 year of motor symptoms; fluctuating cognition; visual hallucinations
differential.tests: Clinical criteria; DaTscan may be abnormal

differential.features: Action tremor > rest tremor; improves with alcohol; family history; no bradykinesia
Gait apraxia ("magnetic gait"); urinary incontinence; dementia
differential.tests: MRI ventricular enlargement; LP with gait improvement

evidence.recommendation: MAO-B inhibitors provide mild motor benefit

monitoring.action: Add adjunct therapy; consider advanced options
Reduce levodopa; add amantadine; adjust timing

monitoring.frequency: Each visit if on dopamine agonist

monitoring.action: PT referral; medication review; home safety evaluation
Hold clozapine if ANC <1000; discontinue if <500

disposition.criteria: Stable motor status; able to take PO; adequate caregiver support; follow-up arranged
Unable to take PO medications >24 hours; severe OFF episode; aspiration pneumonia; acute infection
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome; severe rigidity with rhabdomyolysis; respiratory compromise
Every 3-6 months for stable patients; more frequently during medication adjustments
